The Core Question







üí° Investment Decision


Does co-locating battery storage with solar PV create value, or does it destroy returns compared to standalone BESS deployment?




This report provides infrastructure investors with a comprehensive framework for evaluating battery energy storage system (BESS) investment decisions in Australia‚Äôs National Electricity Market (NEM).

text:
Report Structure

Part I: The Investment Context
Section 1: The Investment Problem ‚Äî Why the historical investment model for pure solar PV is broken, and why capital must pivot to storage-integrated solutions.
Section 2: The BESS Integration Thesis ‚Äî How battery storage restores value to solar assets, and why the market has bifurcated into two distinct deployment models.


Part II: Analysis
Section 3: Trade-off Analysis ‚Äî A direct comparison of standalone vs.¬†co-located deployment models, including strategic advantages and revenue structure analysis.
Section 4: Technical Constraints ‚Äî The ‚Äúhidden killers‚Äù of returns‚Äîrevenue concentration, Marginal Loss Factors, and grid constraints that can make or break battery investments.


Part III: Framework
Section 5: Strategic Framework ‚Äî Step-by-step decision framework for evaluating standalone vs.¬†co-located BESS, with quantitative assessment templates and modeling guidance.

title: 1¬† The Investment Problem
text:
1.1 The End of ‚ÄúPlain‚Äù Solar
The historical investment model for utility-scale solar PV in the Australian National Electricity Market is broken. For years, renewable energy developers relied on long-term fixed-price Power Purchase Agreements (PPAs) spanning 7-15 years to secure project finance. These contracts provided the revenue certainty needed to support high-leverage debt structures typical of infrastructure investments.

title: 1¬† The Investment Problem
text:
üö® The Core Problem


Pure solar is no longer financeable at acceptable risk-adjusted returns in competitive regions of the NEM. The traditional financing waterfall has collapsed.

title: 1¬† The Investment Problem
section: 1.2 The Collapse of the Unfirmed PPA
text:
1.2 The Collapse of the Unfirmed PPA
With the end of the Large-scale Renewable Energy Target (LRET) and rapidly increasing solar penetration, the economics of daytime generation have fundamentally changed. The problem is straightforward: when everyone generates at the same time, prices collapse.

1.2.1 Solar Anti-Correlation
The wholesale electricity price during solar hours (10:00-16:00) in NSW tells the story clearly:



‚òÄÔ∏è Solar Price Collapse & Curtailment Growth

In Progress



üìä


NSW Solar Hour Prices & Curtailment (2018-2025)


Dual-axis chart showing annual average wholesale prices during solar hours (10:00-16:00) in NSW and solar curtailment percentage.


Key Trend: Prices declined from ~$85/MWh (2018) to <$40/MWh (2025) while curtailment increased from <1% to >5%.



Data: AEMO via NEMOSIS (2018-2025) Script: scripts/section1/s1_solar_price_curtailment.py





50%


Decline in solar-hour wholesale prices (2018-2025)


Solar hour wholesale prices in NSW have collapsed from approximately $80-90/MWh to less than $40/MWh, while curtailment has increased from less than 1% to over 5%.



The data reveals two devastating trends for solar investors:

Price Cannibalization: Solar hour wholesale prices have declined by over 50% from 2018 to 2025
Physical Curtailment: Solar generators are not just facing low prices‚Äîthey‚Äôre being physically curtailed due to grid congestion during solar peaks. Curtailment has increased >5x over the same period.


1.2.2 The PPA Problem
Infrastructure investors don‚Äôt just want high prices‚Äîthey need contracted revenue. The challenge is that corporate offtakers increasingly refuse to sign long-term PPAs for plain solar at any price. Why would a commercial buyer lock in a fixed rate for power that‚Äôs only generated when grid prices are lowest?



üìâ



The Broken Financing Waterfall


How uncontracted revenue blocks project finance












Stage
Problem
Consequence




Contracting
Can‚Äôt secure long-term PPA
Revenue uncertainty


Debt sizing
Lenders won‚Äôt underwrite merchant risk
Lower leverage possible


Return hurdles
Reduced debt ‚Üí lower equity returns
Can‚Äôt hit target IRR


Capital deployment
Project doesn‚Äôt proceed
Capital sits idle







1.3 The Certificate Cliff
The revenue problem extends beyond wholesale electricity. Large-scale Generation Certificates (LGCs), which historically provided 30-40% of solar project revenue, have collapsed as the LRET obligation has been fulfilled.


$50 ‚Üí $6.50


LGC price collapse (January 2024 to January 2026)


The certificate market has collapsed by ~87% in just two years as the LRET obligation was fulfilled. This removes a critical revenue stream that historically supported project economics.









‚ö†Ô∏è Regulatory Uncertainty: Guarantees of Origin


The market transitions to a voluntary scheme post-2030 through Guarantees of Origin (GOs). However, GOs include a time-stamp element‚Äîcertificates are matched to the exact hour of consumption.


Just as physical solar-hour power is oversupplied, solar-hour GOs will likely trade at a significant discount to off-peak certificates, further depressing returns.






1.4 The Curtailment Risk
Investors are not just facing revenue risk from low prices. They face volume risk from physical curtailment:



‚ö°



Curtailment Drivers


Why solar farms can‚Äôt always export their generation





Grid congestion: Solar farms in regional NSW are often at the end of transmission lines with limited export capacity
AEMO intervention: Semi-scheduled generators can be directed to reduce output when local network constraints bind
Wasted generation: Curtailed energy represents sunk capital with zero return



For existing solar assets approaching PPA expiry, the prospect of uncontracted merchant exposure to these conditions represents a material valuation risk. A solar farm that can‚Äôt reliably sell its output is an infrastructure asset with a fundamental flaw.



1.5 The Investment Imperative
The conclusion for infrastructure capital is clear: pure solar is no longer financeable at acceptable risk-adjusted returns in competitive regions of the NEM.
Battery energy storage systems (BESS) offer the obvious technical solution‚Äîshift generation from oversupplied daylight hours to valuable evening peaks. But this raises the critical question that motivates this entire analysis:







üí° The Core Investment Question


Should batteries be co-located with solar, or deployed as standalone assets?




The answer determines:

Capital deployment sizing (small vs.¬†large projects)
Revenue structure (contracted vs.¬†merchant)
Location optimization (solar sites vs.¬†grid access points)
Return profiles (infrastructure vs.¬†opportunistic)

The following sections provide a framework for making this decision systematically.



Key Takeaways



Solar hour wholesale prices in NSW have declined >50% from 2018-2025


Curtailment has increased >5x over the same period


LGC revenues have collapsed from $50 to $6.50/certificate


Pure solar PPA contracting has become increasingly difficult


Infrastructure investors face a binary choice: add BESS or accept merchant risk

title: 2¬† The BESS Integration Thesis
text:
2.1 Restoring Value Through Storage
The previous section established that pure solar PV faces fundamental economic challenges in the NEM: price cannibalization, curtailment risk, and an inability to secure long-term contracts. Battery energy storage systems (BESS) offer a path forward.

title: 2¬† The BESS Integration Thesis
text:
üîã



How BESS Solves the Solar Problem


Three value restoration mechanisms





2.1.1 1. Time-Shifting Generation
Batteries can shift solar generation from oversupplied daytime hours to high-value evening peaks:









Period
Solar Output
Battery Action
Value Captured




10:00-16:00
Maximum
Charge
Avoid low/negative prices


16:00-20:00
Declining
Discharge
Capture evening peak ($200-500/MWh)


20:00-06:00
Zero
Hold/Discharge
Respond to overnight volatility



This arbitrage converts low-value midday MWh into high-value evening MWh.


2.1.2 2. Curtailment Protection
Behind-the-meter battery storage can absorb excess solar generation that would otherwise be curtailed:

Grid constraint: Network operator directs solar farm to reduce output
Without battery: Lost generation, zero revenue
With battery: Store curtailed energy, discharge when constraint clears

For solar farms facing 5-10% curtailment, this represents significant recovered revenue.


2.1.3 3. Enabling Contractability
The combination of solar + storage creates a firmable capacity product that offtakers will actually buy:

Plain solar: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll give you power‚Ä¶ when the sun shines‚Ä¶ if we‚Äôre not curtailed‚Äù
Solar + storage: ‚ÄúWe guarantee X MW of firm capacity during Y hours‚Äù

This transforms an intermittent asset into a dispatchable one, enabling long-term PPAs and project finance.

title: 2¬† The BESS Integration Thesis
text:
2.2 The Investor Dilemma
While BESS solves the technical problem, it creates a commercial dilemma. Battery storage does not need to be co-located with solar PV to provide these benefits to the grid. The market is splitting into two distinct investment approaches.







üí° The Core Dilemma


Batteries can time-shift and firm renewable generation from anywhere on the grid. They don‚Äôt need to be physically connected to a solar farm to capture arbitrage value or provide system services.





2.2.1 Two Distinct Asset Classes


2 Models


The market has bifurcated into distinct deployment strategies


Infrastructure investors must choose between optimizing for location and flexibility (standalone) or capital efficiency and product definition (co-located). These are fundamentally different investment theses.



2.2.1.1 Model 1: Standalone BESS



üîã



Standalone Deployment


Battery as independent infrastructure asset




Investment thesis: Maximize battery returns by optimizing location, grid services, and merchant arbitrage.
Key characteristics: - Site selected for optimal MLF and grid access - Full flexibility to charge from grid (including negative pricing) - Independent dispatch optimization - Revenue from arbitrage, FCAS, and capacity payments - Typically 2-4 hour duration for price volatility capture
Investor profile: Merchant-tolerant investors, trading-oriented asset managers, FCAS specialists




2.2.1.2 Model 2: Co-located (Hybrid)



‚ö°



Co-located Deployment


Battery integrated with solar PV asset




Investment thesis: Create a firmable renewable product with infrastructure cost synergies and contracted revenue.
Key characteristics: - Site determined by solar farm location (MLF inherited) - Shared grid connection and infrastructure - ‚ÄúGreen‚Äù product definition for ESG-focused offtakers - CIS eligibility for government-backed contracts - Often longer duration (4+ hours) for firming requirements
Investor profile: Infrastructure funds, yield-focused investors, existing solar asset owners

text:

For new investors evaluating BESS deployment, the question is straightforward but consequential:







üö® Does the Solar Plant Add Value?


For a new build: Does adding solar PV to the battery project increase risk-adjusted returns, or does it constrain location and reduce flexibility?


For a retrofit: Does adding a battery to an existing solar farm preserve the asset‚Äôs value, or would capital be better deployed in a standalone battery elsewhere?

title: 2¬† The BESS Integration Thesis
text:
2.4 Framework for Analysis
The remainder of this report provides a systematic framework for making the standalone vs.¬†co-located decision:


What Follows



Section 3: Trade-off Analysis ‚Äî Detailed comparison of advantages and revenue structures


Section 4: Technical Constraints ‚Äî MLF impact, revenue concentration, and location value


Section 5: Strategic Framework ‚Äî Step-by-step decision process and modeling approach




2.4.1 Decision Hierarchy
The framework follows a logical sequence:

Define the benchmark: What return hurdle must the battery achieve? Is this a new build or retrofit?
Quantify location impact: What is the MLF penalty of co-location? What is the curtailment risk?
Assess contracting options: Is a ‚Äúgreen premium‚Äù available? Is CIS eligibility valuable?
Model the alternatives: Use dispatch optimization to compare scenarios quantitatively
Make the decision: Compare risk-adjusted returns against the benchmark








‚ÑπÔ∏è The Retrofit Exception


For investors with existing solar assets approaching PPA expiry, the decision framework is different. The comparison is not ‚Äústandalone vs.¬†co-located BESS‚Äù but rather ‚Äúco-located BESS vs.¬†uncontracted merchant solar.‚Äù


In this context, a lower battery return may be acceptable if it preserves the value of the solar asset that would otherwise face merchant exposure.

title: 2¬† The BESS Integration Thesis
text:
2.5 Why This Matters
The standalone vs.¬†co-located decision has significant implications for:

2.5.1 Capital Allocation

Standalone: Smaller check size per project, more projects needed
Co-located: Larger check size, fewer but bigger projects

For infrastructure funds with deployment targets, this affects portfolio construction.


2.5.2 Risk Profile

Standalone: Higher merchant exposure, but location-optimized
Co-located: More contractable, but location-constrained

The appropriate choice depends on the investor‚Äôs risk tolerance and return requirements.


2.5.3 Market Structure
As the NEM evolves, the mix of standalone vs.¬†co-located batteries will shape:

Grid stability and congestion patterns
Price formation in different regions
The value of ‚Äúgreen‚Äù vs.¬†‚Äúbrown‚Äù electrons

Understanding these dynamics is essential for long-term investment success.



Key Takeaways



BESS solves solar‚Äôs value problem through time-shifting, curtailment protection, and enabling contractability


Batteries do NOT need to be co-located with solar to provide grid benefits


The market has bifurcated into two distinct models: standalone (location-optimized) and co-located (integration-optimized)


The optimal choice is context-dependent: location quality, contracting needs, existing assets, return targets


Retrofit scenarios have different economics than greenfield development


The following sections provide a systematic framework for making this decision

3.2.3 Strategic Advantages of Standalone BESS

3.2.3.1 1. Siting Freedom
Standalone batteries can be located to maximize grid value rather than accommodate solar farm constraints:








Factor
Standalone Advantage
Co-located Constraint




MLF
Site in high-MLF regions (0.95-1.05)

FCAS

Limited by solar site capabilities


Transmission

End-of-line locations typical










‚ö†Ô∏è Location Lock-in


Solar farms are typically located based on land availability and solar resource. These sites often have poor MLFs and face transmission constraints. Forcing a battery to share this location destroys arbitrage value.






3.2.3.2 2. Speed to Market
Standalone BESS projects can be deployed significantly faster:



Project Type
Typical Timeline




BESS only
12-18 months


PV + BESS
24-36 months


Modular augmentation
6-12 months



For investors targeting near-term deployment to capture current market conditions, standalone provides critical time advantages.


3.2.3.3 3. Asset Lifecycle Independence
Battery and solar have fundamentally different operational lives:

BESS: 15-20 years before major augmentation/replacement needed
PV: 30-35 years asset life
Mismatch risk: Battery reaches end-of-life while PV continues operating

Standalone deployment avoids the complexity of shared infrastructure replacement decisions and misaligned ownership structures.


3.2.3.4 4. Negative Pricing Revenue


Double-dip


Revenue from negative pricing: get paid to charge, then paid to discharge


When wholesale prices go negative (excess solar), standalone batteries get paid to charge and can discharge hours later at positive prices. This revenue stream is largely unavailable to co-located batteries.


Co-located batteries can charge during negative prices, but only by curtailing their own solar generation to create grid import capacity. This is rarely economically optimal.



3.2.4 The ‚ÄúPure Merchant‚Äù Misconception







‚ÑπÔ∏è Standalone ‚â† Merchant


Standalone BESS are not synonymous with pure merchant/volatility exposure. Many operate under:



Tolling agreements: Fixed capacity payments + merchant upside


FCAS contracts: Firm grid services revenue


CfD structures: Contracted arbitrage with price hedging


CIS contracts: Government-backed revenue floor



The key distinction is that standalone batteries choose location to maximize these revenue opportunities.

Reduced financing cost (government credit support)
Competitive advantage vs.¬†standalone (which may not qualify)

Structure new PPA for shaped delivery

3.4 Revenue Structure: Where Batteries Make Money

Critical observations:

Base revenue is minimal: ‚ÄúNormal‚Äù market conditions ($0-300/MWh) contribute relatively little. Battery economics depend on price volatility, not average prices.

3.5 Decision Framework Summary

3.5.1 Configuration Choice Drivers
Choose Non-hybrid when: - MLF differential is significant between sites - Battery targets different revenue streams (FCAS, different price zone) - Maximum dispatch flexibility required
Choose AC-coupled when: - Capex savings are material - Independent dispatch still valuable - Common retrofit scenario
Choose DC-coupled when: - Creating ‚Äúguaranteed green‚Äù product (corporate PPA requirement) - Grid charging explicitly unwanted - Maximum capex savings prioritized
The configuration choice is not purely technical‚Äîit‚Äôs driven by commercial objectives (PPA structure, green premium, financing requirements).



Key Takeaways



BESS deployment has grown rapidly: 500 MWh (2019) ‚Üí 10,000+ MWh (2026-2027 projected)


Majority of current batteries are standalone, optimizing for location and flexibility


Standalone advantages: siting freedom, speed, lifecycle independence, negative pricing revenue


Co-located advantages: capex synergies ($50-100/kW), capital deployment scale, green premium, retrofit logic


Battery revenue is highly concentrated in negative pricing and extreme high-price events


DC-coupled configurations forfeit grid charging revenue (significant opportunity cost)


Configuration choice is driven by commercial objectives, not purely technical factors


Decision is context-dependent: new build vs.¬†retrofit, return targets, contracting options

title: 4¬† Technical Constraints & Location Value
text:
4.1 The Revenue Concentration Problem
Battery revenue in the NEM is not evenly distributed across time. A small fraction of hours drive the majority of returns, making location optimization critical for economic viability.

title: 4¬† Technical Constraints & Location Value
text:
4.1.1 Revenue Skew: The 80/20 Reality
The following analysis examines NSW batteries operational throughout 2025, plotting cumulative revenue against cumulative time (hours sorted by revenue descending):



üìä Battery Revenue Concentration: NSW 2025

50% in 10%


Half of annual revenue generated in just one-tenth of operating hours


Battery economics depend entirely on capturing extreme price events. Missing even a few of these critical hours‚Äîdue to curtailment, poor MLF, or grid constraints‚Äîmaterially impacts annual returns.


Critical implications:

Extreme concentration: 50% of annual revenue is generated in just ~10% of operating hours
Volatility dependence: Battery economics depend on price extremes, not average prices
Location sensitivity: Missing key high-price events (due to curtailment, poor MLF, or grid constraints) materially impacts returns








‚ö†Ô∏è Why This Matters for Co-location



DC-coupled batteries may miss high-price discharge events if solar is generating (constrained by inverter capacity)


Poor MLF locations compound revenue loss during critical high-price periods


Transmission curtailment disproportionately impacts returns by eliminating top revenue hours





The investment decision hinges on capturing these fat-tail events. Standalone batteries optimize for this by siting in high-MLF locations with minimal curtailment risk.

4.2 Marginal Loss Factors: The Hidden Tax

4.2.1 Understanding MLF Impact
Marginal Loss Factors (MLFs) represent the energy lost when electricity passes through the transmission network. Generators are paid (or pay) based on MLF-adjusted prices:

Example calculation: If wholesale price = $100/MWh and MLF = 0.90:

Generator receives: $100 √ó 0.90 = $90/MWh

‚ÑπÔ∏è MLF Impact on Battery Arbitrage


For batteries arbitraging price spreads, MLF affects both discharge revenue and charging cost:



Discharge: Revenue discounted by MLF


Charge: Cost discounted by MLF (pay less to charge)



Net impact depends on price spread and MLF differential between charge/discharge locations.

title: 4¬† Technical Constraints & Location Value
text:
4.4 Network Constraints and Curtailment Risk

4.4.1 The Transmission Bottleneck
Even with favorable MLF, batteries face curtailment risk when transmission networks are constrained. This disproportionately impacts revenue by eliminating top-earning hours.
Curtailment mechanisms:

System security constraints: Generator output restricted to maintain frequency/stability
Network limits: Transmission lines at capacity, exports restricted
Local network issues: Voltage or thermal limits in distribution networks








üö® Impact on Revenue Concentration


Since 50% of revenue comes from ~10% of hours (typically high-price periods with tight system conditions), curtailment during these events has an outsized impact on annual returns.




Co-location vulnerability:

Solar-heavy regions face more curtailment (midday surplus)
Co-located batteries may be curtailed when solar is exporting (network constraint)
Behind-the-meter batteries forced to charge/discharge to match solar, missing optimal arbitrage windows

Standalone advantage:

Independent dispatch can respond to market signals without solar constraints
High-MLF locations typically have better transmission access
FCAS services provide alternative revenue during curtailment events

title: 4¬† Technical Constraints & Location Value
text:
4.5 The Location Optimization Framework

4.5.1 Site Selection Hierarchy
For battery investors, location optimization follows a clear hierarchy:

MLF maximization (primary revenue driver)
Curtailment risk minimization (protect top-decile revenue hours)
Price volatility exposure (ensure sufficient price spread)
FCAS market access (ancillary services revenue)
Transmission capacity (ability to export full capacity)



4.5.2 When Co-location Makes Sense



‚ö°



Co-location Can Be Optimal When:


Conditions favoring hybrid deployment





Grid upgrades planned: Transmission improvements will improve MLF/reduce curtailment
Green premium sufficient: ESG buyers pay enough to offset MLF penalty
Retrofit scenario: Adding battery to existing solar (location constraint already exists)
CIS eligibility: Government contracts compensate for location disadvantage





4.5.3 When Standalone Is Preferred



üîã



Standalone Is Preferred When:


Conditions favoring independent deployment





Greenfield development: Free to choose optimal location
Merchant exposure: Targeting pure arbitrage without PPA protection
High hurdle rates: Need maximum revenue per MW
FCAS focus: Ancillary services revenue is significant

title: 4¬† Technical Constraints & Location Value
text:
4.6 Beyond Revenue: Operational Considerations

4.6.1 Battery Duration and MLF Sensitivity
Longer-duration batteries (4hr+) are less sensitive to MLF than 2hr systems because:

Fewer cycles: Lower annual revenue per MW capacity, so MLF impact is diluted
Energy arbitrage focus: Capturing day-night spread rather than intraday volatility
Capacity payments: May be contracted for capacity rather than energy arbitrage

However, 2hr batteries (the current market standard) are highly MLF-sensitive because they rely on rapid cycling during price spikes ‚Äî the exact events where MLF adjusts the absolute revenue.


4.6.2 Degradation and Revenue Quality
High-MLF locations often correlate with:

More cycling: Volatile prices = frequent charge/discharge = faster degradation
Higher temperatures: Load centers = hotter climate = reduced battery life

Investors must balance:

Higher revenue (good MLF) vs Higher opex (increased maintenance, shorter replacement cycle)

Standalone batteries in high-MLF locations may face 15-20% higher degradation rates than co-located batteries in milder climates ‚Äî partially offsetting the revenue advantage.



Key Takeaways



Battery revenue is highly concentrated: 50% of revenue from ~10% of hours


MLF materially impacts returns: 15-25% revenue difference between poor (0.85) and excellent (0.98) locations


Solar farms typically have poor MLFs (0.80-0.90) due to end-of-line siting


Standalone batteries can access high-MLF locations (0.95-1.05) near load centers


Curtailment risk disproportionately impacts returns by eliminating top revenue hours


Location-driven revenue differential often exceeds capex savings from co-location


Duration matters: 2hr batteries more MLF-sensitive than 4hr+ systems


Operational factors (degradation, temperature) partially offset high-MLF advantages

Decision Summary


Synthesizing the analysis




If greenfield and location-flexible: - Default to standalone unless co-location provides clear IRR advantage - Location value typically exceeds infrastructure synergies
If greenfield but CIS-dependent: - Co-location likely preferred for eligibility - Accept some location penalty for financing benefit
If retrofit with expiring PPA: - Co-location typically preferred - Battery protects solar asset value - Lower battery IRR acceptable if combined returns meet hurdle
If retrofit but solar has strong MLF: - Evaluate standalone at same site (AC-coupled, separate DUID) - May capture both location value and synergies










üö® Remember


This framework provides structure, but every project is unique. The quantitative analysis should inform‚Äînot replace‚Äîcommercial judgment. Engage technical and financial advisors to validate assumptions before committing capital.







Key Takeaways



First classify your scenario: greenfield vs.¬†retrofit changes the decision framework


Establish a clear return benchmark before evaluating options


Quantify location value (MLF impact) and infrastructure synergies separately


Consider contracting requirements: green premium, CIS eligibility, PPA structure


Use dispatch modeling to validate assumptions and test sensitivities


For greenfield: standalone typically wins unless specific co-location benefits apply


For retrofit: co-location typically wins as it protects existing solar value


Every project is unique‚Äîuse this framework as a guide, not a prescription
